title: Genomic Epidemiology and Public Health
text:
Welcome!
GenomicEpi.com is dedicated to providing resources for the genomic and molecular epidemiology community. You’ll find various pages with information about trainings, graduate programs, and genomic epidemiology jobs.
Please look around, and reach out if there are any resources you think would be helpful that aren’t included.


Public Health | Epidemiology | Molecular Biology
The last decade has brought about incredible advances in sequencing technologies, which have increasingly been leveraged for public health surveillance as well as outbreak detection and investigation. Successfully using genomic data requires a collaborative team and expertise across multiple disciplines including laboratory science, bioinformatics, and epidemiology. It has been exciting to see over the past decade how each of these fields has evolved.

title: Training Resources
Genomic Epi Jobs
text:
Are you interested in finding a job in genomic epidemiology, or do you have a genomic epidemiology job to submit? You’ve come to the right place! The focus is on pathogen genomics in public health, but related jobs in academia or industry as welcome as well.

Job listings




Submit a job




Newsletter

title: Genomic Epi Graduate Programs
text:
Are you interested in a graduate program in genomic epidemiology, or do you have a genomic epidemiology program you’d like to share? You’ve come to the right place!
This is intended to be a broad listing of both programs that are specifically focused on genomic epidemiology or closely-related disciplines, but also programs such as epidemiology PhD programs that have advisors available to allow students to complete genomic epidemiology focused research.

Program listing




Submit a program




Newsletter

About Me
Krisandra Allen, MPH, MB(ASCP)CM
I’m an epidemiologist with a background in molecular biology and experience in public health at a local health department, state health department, public health laboratory, and in the private sector. My favorite area of public health practice has always been foodborne and enteric disease, and I have a special place in my heart for norovirus (and once held the official job title of “norovirus epidemiology specialist”). I love bringing together my two areas of experience (lab + epi) to advance the use of genomic epidemiology in public health.
I maintain this site to create a place to pull together resources and materials that can benefit the community. If you have anything you think would be helpful on the site, please reach out with recommendations!



Sunrise in Kingston, Washington

title: Newsletter
text:
I periodically publish a newsletter that covers topics ranging from my career experience in public health to genomic epidemiology current topics. See the most recent posts below, and visit https://genomicepi.substack.com/ to view all posts and subscribe.
Do you have something you think would be a great topic? Reach out and I’m happy to work with you if it fits the genomic epidemiology theme!

title: Making learning about antimicrobial resistance fun
text:
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global concern, and one of the challenges of raising awareness is the complexity of the problem. There are so many different pathogens and resistance mechanisms!
Enter, games! Games are a great way to introduce complex topics in a fun and engaging way.
Pathogen Pursuit: A Hospital Whodunit is a classic mystery game, but instead of solving a murder, players race to solve an outbreak in a hospital! The game features different Carbapenemase-producing Enterobacterales and an intrepid outbreak investigation team.






Coming soon!



A printable version will be shared here soon!
